Answer: No, and in fact, quite the contrary. Humans have now quite considerably “devolved” as a direct result of technology. By “devolved” I mean become less sustainable and less biologically secure.Humanity has now become substantially genetically impaired by technology and is now streaming into a mass extinction event as a direct outcome.Our planet has now been compelled into a magnetic collapse situation that will destroy the capacity to continue this technological mutation unless major understandings about technology are implemented within the next few years.
name: Franklin Veaux

For instance, some people are more resistant to this novel coronavirus than others, either due to their physical makeup or tendency towards healthy lifestyle choices. This outbreak will tend to weigh the surviving population towards those who have genetically better resistance for one reason or another. That is how evolution works.I’m not trying to be cold towards those suffering. I believe I may have the virus myself, and have an 87 year old father to worry about. I am anxious and upset. Answer: Question: Is it better for humans to evolve technology than to evolve their gene pool?These are not mutually exclusive.The time it took evolution to go from this:to this:Technology also went from this:to this:The thing is: we can control technology. Evolution involves random chance and waiting for a favorable mutation to occur and then be propagated down the millennia to the rest of the human race, or at least a significant portion. Significant change through evolution takes millions of years. Significant technological change has no minimum or maximum time constraints.Question: Is it better for humans to evolve technology than to evolve their gene pool?These are not mutually exclusive.The time it took evolution to go from this:to this:Technology also went from this:to this:The thing is: we can control technology. question: https://www.quora.com/Does-the-considerable-advancement-of-technology-mean-that-humans-have-actually-evolved

Answer: If someone can describe a method to “evolve our gene pool” I will be fascinated, if also skeptical.Of course we have been in a race to grow/improve/expand our technology since the beginning of human civilization. In the past five or so centuries it has been picking up speed, and to the detriment of “the gene pool.” Conditions which were fatal, two years to five centuries ago, are now survivable, hence the fuzz that accumulates “in our gene pool” isn’t being elimitated at the same rate as before.Every human cell division involves roughly 50 spontaneous mutations, a.k.a. copy errors. When the toIf someone can describe a method to “evolve our gene pool” I will be fascinated, if also skeptical.Of course we have been in a race to grow/improve/expand our technology since the beginning of human civilization. In the past five or so centuries it has been picking up speed, and to the detriment of “the gene pool.” Conditions which were fatal, two years to five centuries ago, are now survivable, hence the fuzz that accumulates “in our gene pool” isn’t being elimitated at the same rate as before.Every human cell division involves roughly 50 spontaneous mutations, a.k.a. copy errors. When the total is six billion nucleotides, fifty is about on the scale of belly button lint with regard to normal health.But from the initial fertilized egg out to the germ cell (egg or sperm) that initiates a new generation, a lot of cell divisions take place. On the good side, this is evolution in the flesh, unstoppable. Species adapt to whatever environment they live in, and over time if the environment doesn’t change, the ability of a “good” mutation to spread throughout the gene pool becomes less and less.When the environment changes, and over hundred-thousand to many-million year spans, count on that happening, that fuzz effect of cell division allows for necessary changes to sweep through the breeding population.But keeping bad genes in the pool poses inevitable long term challenges.
name: Franklin Veaux

Answer: Yes.Evolution operates on populations of memes, which is to say units of information. Our genes are just one type of meme, encoded in DNA.All of our technologies, which range from smartphones and nuclear reactors and clothes to more abstract things like language and the concept of privacy, are also memes.Each technological idea is its own species of meme, and just as we rely on symbiotic relationsYes.Evolution operates on populations of memes, which is to say units of information. Our genes are just one type of meme, encoded in DNA.All of our technologies, which range from smartphones and nuclear reactors and clothes to more abstract things like language and the concept of privacy, are also memes.Each technological idea is its own species of meme, and just as we rely on symbiotic relationships with mitochondria and gut bacteria and the like to live, we rely on symbiotic relationships with our technologies.One particularly useful property of our technology is that we can selectively breed and thereby evolve memes much, much faster by not encoding them in DNA, but instead in arrangements of neurons and ink on paper and electrical charges in silicon.One of the main reasons for this, one of the reasons symbiosis is so critical, is, simply, that evolution applies to populations across generations, and the shorter the generations the faster evolution can work. Humans, alas, have some of the longest generations on the planet to as to better reap the benefits of out symbioses.It took billions of years for DNA to evolve intelligent life. It will take...

question: https://www.quora.com/Does-the-considerable-advancement-of-technology-mean-that-humans-have-actually-evolved

Answer: It wouldn't have. In fact modern human hands evolved among our ancestors millions of years before our brains did. You could say our brains evolved to make fuller use of the possibilities afforded by our hands.Gibbons, our most distant Great Ape cousins, lack opposable thumbs because they're get in the way of swinging through the forest canopy. Conversely, we need thumbs to hold/throw/manipulate objects--all prerequisites to making and employing weapons that can act at a distance (rocks, throwing spears, atlatls, bows/arrows)
name: Samuel Bateman
question: https://www.quora.com/Does-the-considerable-advancement-of-technology-mean-that-humans-have-actually-evolved

Answer: Even before tool use, our ancestors were probably the best in the animal kingdom at throwing things, which also benefits from an opposable thumb.  So overall, I think it is unlikely humans would have split off from our ape brethren in the way they did, without the thumb.  They may have never successfully moved into the savannah, and instead remained in the forests and never split from the chimps.  If they did move into the savannah, still, the lack of a thumb is going to massively slow down "technology," which could be as simple as building a fire or ability to smash open a bone of a picked ovEven before tool use, our ancestors were probably the best in the animal kingdom at throwing things, which also benefits from an opposable thumb.  So overall, I think it is unlikely humans would have split off from our ape brethren in the way they did, without the thumb.  They may have never successfully moved into the savannah, and instead remained in the forests and never split from the chimps.  If they did move into the savannah, still, the lack of a thumb is going to massively slow down "technology," which could be as simple as building a fire or ability to smash open a bone of a picked over carcass to get the marrow.  Without such technology, the brain wouldn't have had strong selective pressure to become smarter than the other apes.Then again, the apes in the forests depended on their thumbs for climbing, so this is all quite hypothetical.

Answer: The first computer I ever used was the IBM 1620, the only computer on the campus of the Australian National University when I started there in 1965.It did its internal arithmetic in decimal using lookup tables, although this was transparent to FORTRAN 2 users like me.Wikipedia lists several “Notable uses” for the IBM 1620. One of them is “In 1964 at the Australian National University, Martin Ward used an IBM 1620 model I to calculate the order of the Janko group J_1.”In June 2018 when I was going to the ANU gym I saw Martin Ward sitting in the coffee shop at the sports centre.
